title: Brexit minister says it will take 'years' before Britain's economy can work without EU migrants

The Brexit minister has said the UK will keep its doors open to low-skilled EU migrants as British citizens are not yet ready to fill jobs in farming, care and service. 
David Davis MP, who in December 2015 said the “disastrous migration crisis” was why he’d vote Leave the following summer, indicated that it will be some time yet before Britain can plug the gap. What has he said? 
Mr Davis, who is the cabinet minister tasked with making a success out of leaving the European Union , has been visiting the Estonian capital, Tallinn. 
He told Bloomberg that Britain will not be able to fill some jobs without importing labour from the continent. 
These include roles in farming, restaurants and looking after the elderly. 
He said: “In the hospitality sector, hotels and restaurants, in the social care sector, working in agriculture, it will take time - it will be years and years before we get British citizens to do those jobs,” 
“Don’t expect just because we’re changing who makes the decision on the policy, the door will suddenly shut: it won’t,” Why can’t British people take the jobs? A combine harvester in a field, as Brexit could lead to a labour shortage which sees fruit and vegetable crops go unharvested and businesses close down, farming leaders have warned (Photo: PA) 
Well, Mr Davis said it will be a while before British workers can replace people who come to Britain and graft for low wages. 
He said: “Even on the wider area, where we’ve got less well-paid people who have come to live and work in Britain, that will take time.” 
He also says Britain has a “successful economy, largely or partly at least because we have clever people, talented people come to Britain.” Do any other prominent Leavers agree? 
In June, Environment secretary Andrea Leadsom warned immigration could “overwhelm” Britain. 
But in January, Mrs Leadsom - who is quoted in the Guardian saying her family lived in Portugal for 10 years - had to reassure farmers that they would still be able to hire labour from Europe.
